work.p: These lines bear a distant resemblance to ideas used in the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself." In The Complete Writings of Walt Whitman, Vol. 3, ed. Oliver Lovell Triggs (New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons, 1902), the lines are connected to what would become section 3 of "Song of Myself": "I have heard what the talkers were talking, the talk of the beginning and the end, ... Exactly the value of one and exactly the value of two, and which is ahead?" (1891, pp. 30–31).

titleStmt.title: I ask nobody's faith
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The paper and ink are similar to that used for other early poetry manuscripts. In his transcription of this manuscript, Richard Maurice Bucke combines it with "Do I not prove myself," but the manuscripts do not appear to be continuous (Notes and Fragments [London, Ontario: A. Talbot & Co., printers, 1899], 25).

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Holograph literary fragments and notes for poems, on 47 paper slips, tipped into 3 volumes
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

add.l: I ask nobody's faith . . . . . I am very little concerned about that

lg.l: When Do yYou doubt not the east and the west,
When Do yYou doubt not your desires and or your finger‑nails,
When Do yYou doubt not iron metal water or acid or steam,
